sections.title: Nine Joys of Life and the Tenth Bitter Thing

verses.text: Three things delight my soul, and they are beautiful to the Lord and to mankind: harmony among brothers, friendship between neighbors, and a wife and husband who live together in unity.
verses.comment: This verse highlights the spiritual beauty of harmony within families and communities. The emphasis on unity between spouses prefigures the indissoluble bond of marriage, which is a sign not only of human affection but also points toward the unity Christ desires between Himself and the Church (see Eph. 5:31-32).

verses.text: There are three types of people my soul hates, and their whole manner of living is deeply offensive: a proud beggar, a rich liar, and an adulterous old man lacking wisdom.
verses.comment: The mention of hatred for certain vices serves as a strong warning against hypocrisy and moral failure, especially in old age where wisdom is expected. Note the trilogies of virtue and vice emphasized in wisdom literature.

verses.text: If you have not gathered wisdom in your youth, how can you find it in your old age?
verses.comment: The exhortation to embrace wisdom early is a frequent biblical theme. The spiritual interpretation points to a lifetime of formation, echoing the tradition of spiritual discipline from youth.

verses.text: How lovely is sound judgment in gray-haired elders, and wisdom found among aged people.
verses.comment: Wisdom and honorable old age are linked here; elders are seen as possessors of spiritual treasures within the community of faith.

verses.text: How good it is to learn from those who are experienced, to listen to wise counsel from older men.
verses.comment: This reminds believers of the value of tradition—learning from the wisdom transmitted by those who have lived faithfully before us.

verses.text: Rich experience is the crown of elders, and fearing the Lord gives glory to old age.
verses.comment: Spiritual maturity and reverence for God elevate and dignify the years of one's life, blending the literal and spiritual interpretation of wisdom tradition.

verses.text: I count nine things to be happy about in my heart, and a tenth I will speak too: a man who rejoices in his children; one who lives to see the downfall of his enemies;
verses.comment: Sirach employs the common wisdom motif of numbered sayings. The listed blessings point to family joy and vindication from adversaries as marks of a blessed life.
verses.sectionHeader: Nine Joys of Life and the Tenth Bitter Thing

verses.text: a man who lives with a sensible wife; one who does not stumble with his tongue; one who has not served someone less worthy than himself;
verses.comment: Here, the value of integrity, prudent speech and dignified life are listed. The wife’s virtue recalls the biblical emphasis on a wise and faithful spouse.

verses.text: one who gains wisdom himself; one who speaks before attentive listeners.
verses.comment: Personal acquisition of wisdom and teaching others resonate as ideals within the community of faith. There’s an implicit spiritual element here, as the act of speaking to receptive listeners echoes the apostolic transmission of faith.

verses.text: How great is the one who finds wisdom! But even greater is the one who fears the Lord.
verses.comment: Fearing the Lord is consistently described as superior—even to wisdom itself—in both Proverbs and Psalms. The spiritual interpretation suggests reverence supersedes mere intellectual attainment.

verses.text: There is nothing more powerful than the fear of the Lord, and nothing surpasses it in greatness.
verses.comment: The fear of the Lord is the bedrock of wisdom, a theme extending through both the Old and New Testaments. True spiritual strength flows from reverence of God rather than worldly achievements.

verses.text: [Note: Many manuscripts omit verse 12; commonly absent in several traditions.]
verses.comment: This verse is omitted in several major manuscripts. The omission shows textual fluidity among wisdom books; many translations skip from 11 to 13.

verses.text: Any wound, except the wound of the heart; any wickedness, except the wickedness of a woman;
verses.comment: The verse uses hyperbolic language to warn against relational and spiritual wounds. In a spiritual sense, it calls for an interior purity and integrity in relationships.

verses.text: Any attack, except the attack of those who hate you; any vengeance, except the vengeance of enemies.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes the depth of interpersonal conflicts, but the spiritual meaning looks forward to Jesus' teaching on forgiveness (see Matt. 5:44), pointing to a higher law of love.

verses.text: There is no venom worse than a snake’s venom, and no anger worse than a woman’s wrath.
verses.comment: This verse reflects ancient wisdom traditions that often used vivid imagery and hyperbole, here comparing the destructive potential of unchecked anger—specifically in the context of marital conflict—to the danger of venom, paralleling similar warnings against wrath in Proverbs 21:19 and highlighting the need for harmony within the household.

verses.text: I would rather live with a lion or a dragon than live with a wicked woman.
verses.comment: This hyperbolic warning continues traditional wisdom’s cautions about harmful relationships. In context, it highlights the need for choosing spouses with virtue and faith.

verses.text: The wickedness of a woman changes her appearance, and darkens her face like a bear.
verses.comment: In ancient wisdom literature, external beauty is linked to inner goodness. The teaching promotes an understanding that true beauty flows from purity of heart.

verses.text: Her husband sits among his neighbors, and he sighs bitterly.
verses.comment: The social consequences of broken family relationships are made clear here, anticipating New Testament advice for peace and unity in the home.

verses.text: Any evil is small compared to the evil of a woman; may punishment fall on her, which is the lot of sinners.
verses.comment: Strong language warns against moral corruption; tradition understands such verses as general warnings against all vice and sinfulness, not singularly gendered condemnation.

verses.text: Like a sandy hill to the feet of the aged, so is a talkative wife to a quiet husband.
verses.comment: The comparison illustrates marital discord. The spiritual interpretation encourages patience and forbearance in married life.

verses.text: Do not be led by beauty in a woman, and do not desire her for her looks.
verses.comment: Both Scripture and tradition warn against being swayed by outward appearance (see 1 Sam. 16:7), pointing instead to virtue and grace.

verses.text: Anger, shame, and disgrace arise where a wife dominates her husband.
verses.comment: This verse reflects ancient social norms. Spiritual interpretation calls for mutual respect and sacrificial love in marriage, in line with New Testament teaching.

verses.text: A discouraged heart, a downcast look, and a wounded spirit come from a wicked wife. Weak hands and trembling knees come from a wife who does not bring happiness to her husband.
verses.comment: The spiritual reading recognizes these symptoms as emblematic of broken relationships and urges the pursuit of virtue to heal the family.

verses.text: From a woman sin began, and because of her we all die.
verses.comment: This echoes the story of the Fall (Gen 3). However, tradition also remembers the role of Mary as the 'new Eve', whose obedience reverses Eve’s disobedience (see Luke 1:38), offering hope in Christ.

verses.text: Allow no outlet to water, and no boldness of speech to an evil wife.
verses.comment: Using the metaphor of restraining water to prevent disaster, this proverb cautions against permitting destructive speech in domestic relationships, echoing the biblical theme of guarding one's tongue (Proverbs 21:23) and the classical belief in maintaining order and discipline within the family.

verses.text: If she will not do as you say, separate her from yourself.
verses.comment: This verse must be read in context, balancing wisdom literature’s practical advice with New Testament teaching on love and reconciliation in marriage. Jesus calls for forgiveness and sacrificial love as the true fulfillment of marital fidelity.
